The film "Black or White" is a moving story that drives home that love truly knows no boundaries but the love of a child when it is centered on what is really best for that one little girl, Eloise. Elliot Anderson (Kevin Costner) is the grandfather of Eloise (Jillian Estell) and is suddenly in the position of raising her alone after his wife unexpectedly passes away in an accident. He has loved this young girl all of his life and is also being challenged for custody from her paternal grandmother, Rowena Jeffers (Octavia Spencer) with the aid of her brother, Jeremiah Jeffers (Anthony Mackie). The trouble is that both families deeply love the granddaughter. With Eloise now being torn between the families that she loves who are struggling with their own flaws, things may get complicated in this based on a real events story.

Elliot is a loving and a settled down family sort of man while having a particular maladaptive vice of his own. His family, including his daughter and the mother of Eloise, are caucasian. Because she died while giving birth the child was in her grandparent's care. He can be gruff with an 'interesting' sense of humor and wit, but his adoration of his granddaughter is very clear to see, feel and know. The father of Eloise had been an irresponsible man at that time although his side of the family is deeply rooted and large while also being in love with her and wanting her living with them. While they both have her best intentions at heart, they will not deny their legal claim to her and this does become a battle. This father's family are African American having certain things unfolding throughout that deepen your emotional pull toward a gruff Elliot and Eloise staying a close family. Eloise inevitably goes through changes from being pulled between both her families while we watch her become saddened and swing back and forth from being the loving carefree child to becoming conflicted with their decision and how she should feel toward both of her 'families'. She does truly love them both. While each side does decide to fight for her, they also have to dig deep to explore their own opinions about race and racism along with their stances on the deep and powerful subject and with which family she should belong with. They must all look into understanding the best situation for Eloise first as she is absolutely the heart of the matter and with that comes much understanding and subsequent forgiveness of the pain caused throughout it all.

There is some gorgeously done dialog within this story that is incredibly real, heartfelt, poignant especially by Octavia Spencer and even humorous in places. The families take this to court in front of the sitting Judge who may cause feelings if you are solely looking at her ethnicity that the deck is definitely stacked against Elliot. She is the one to decide the matter of little Eloise. Things get heated and accusations fly about Elliot being a racist, and it appears damaging when it is tossed around a bit much. The father's side of the family begins using tactics of words, viewpoints, and presumptions while the film does succeed in trying to avoid cliches. It could be harmful to them to actually look back at themselves, but they cannot see into their own dysfunctional lives as well as Elliot needs to for his own sake also. There are problems concerning both families including love. Things get moving and the reasons why come out more so when Elliot takes the stand in the case. Just when you believe all the things will swing one way or the other, the facts come out more so towards the end of the story.

There is humorous care included in this film and a strength of character in Elliot and Rowena which is easy to see and appreciate from both. Their love of Eloise takes a giant leap forward in its importance. Writer and director Mike Binder gives us the story of a family for Eloise with a huge amount of heavy emotion. He treats his characters with an obvious ability to forgive, a certain grace, an abundance of grit including all the foibles and the misgivings of imperfect people who are accepting the flaws in their own lives. The film itself is not about the legal battle or the custody so much but about the two assumed different worlds where nothing is ever black or white - but overwhelmingly gray. This is what makes this powerful film so worth the watch.

Heres an Oscar-worthy performance by Kevin Costner in a fairly subdued and glum role, totally believable, with strengths and weaknesses of character and a situation that would make anyone feel sympathetic toward him.  His acting style in this movie resembles Gary Coopers late stage of acting, with subdued emotion, a wry sense of humor, a lot of heaviness from burdensome experiences, and yet still at heart a decent guy.  In this story, he is suddenly made a widower after his wife dies in a car accident.  He is raising his biracial granddaughter, the product of his daughter who died in childbirth and an irresponsible black man, but the illegitimate fathers black family wants custody over the child.  A protracted court battle results.  There are details about the interfamilial conflicts which continue to unfold through the movie and increase the emotional attachment we have to Costner and his granddaughter.  His granddaughter goes through a drastic change from happy and optimistic to tormented about whether she wants her grandfather (Costner) or her black father more, and her relationship with Costner plays out very powerfully.  There are few movies with as authentic of human interactions through the whole movie as this oneno artificial moments that remind me Im watching a movie, just a lot of real dialogue and realistic plot developments which make me really care about the outcome.  I am pleased to say the ending is truly satisfying.  There were times I really feared it wouldnt be.  I am glad this movie was made because it provides inspiration that things can have good results even if the journey is long and complicated.

As for the title, there is a somewhat political tone to the movie also, in that the black family is determined to use charges of Costners racism against him, even though hes not racist, so that they can gain custody.  They are so blinded by false assumptions about the old white guy vs. the black victim that they don't care what they're doing to Costner, nor see the deep dysfunctionality in their own family.  Complicating it further is the fact that its a black female judge whos hearing and deciding this case.  On the surface, the odds are totally stacked against Costner, and his struggle with drinking his problems away makes the tension even greater.  Youd have to see the movie to find out what happens!  (You could read a synopsis, but its not going to be nearly as powerful as seeing the movie.)

The complexity is admirable in that you don't view Costner or the black family stereotypically.  They each have pros and cons.  It's interesting to hear one of the black people say at some point that if they don't shape up, they'll be proving the stereotypes true.  Kevin Costner was passionate enough about its noble theme of getting along with people who are different from you, that he funded it with his own money.

The film centers around a court battle for custody between a rich white alcoholic grandfather and a black  crack-head father.  Kevin Costner plays a poorly scripted drunk who loves his granddaughter Eloise (Jillian Estell) and wants the best for her. When his wife dies, he must care for her himself.

For some reason they decide to give us the background information late. His daughter was the mother who died in child birth while dad did time in prison. Octavia Spencer plays the paternal grandmother who feels she is also entitled to custody having a large family on the South Side.

The film is humorous, heartwarming, and gritty as it takes a more realistic view on race and the race card which climaxes near the end as Costner takes the stand. A far more realistic look at race relations than "Dear White People."

I personally did not hear about this movie nor any advertisement of it until I saw it at the public library.  Black or White, written and directed by Mike Binder, is an interesting story of not only interpersonal relationships but race and cultural relationships. Oscar Winners, Kevin Costner (Elliott), and Octavia Spencer (Rowena aka Weewee) plays the grandparents of Eloise Anderson (played by Jillian Estell) who lives in two different worlds, black and white.

Each grandparent must decide as to how to raise their grandchild, Eloise.  Elliott is a drunkard attorney that feels challenged due to the loss of both his wife and his daughter (Eloise's mother that died at birth). He despises the connection with Rowena and doesn't want anything to do with her nor her side of the family.  Rowena is the matriarch of her family and doing really well for herself.  She provides not only emotional support but financial support as well for her close-knit and extended family. It is her passion to have Eloise be joined with her and her family.

Elliott and Rowena begins a struggle to determine who has the best interest of Eloise, let the journey begin.

The thing I admire most about this film is how truthfully it portrays the racial divide in this country by not painting it in extreme hues but showing it for the immense gray area that it is.  The custody battle at the heart of the film serves as an appropriate metaphor for the current national mindset. Avoiding clich the complexity of director Mike Binder's script and lack of finger pointing and fairness to all sides present in the narrative is commendable.  If I were to fault the film it would be that after raising so many cogent points and posing so many intriguing questions it wraps things up a little too neatly for my taste.  The ending seemed tacked on like it came from a lesser Shyamalan film than from a compelling social drama.  Regardless, the film is a success on so many levels not the least Kevin Costner's sterling turn as the loving but troubled maternal grandfather that I would be remiss not to give it a virtual wholehearted recommendation. This is not to diminish the work of Octavia Spencer as the fiercely independent paternal grandmother and the rest of the talented ensemble but the power of Costner's performance permeates the film.  Definitely one of last year's overlooked gems.

Writer director Mike Binder has created one of more sensitive films dealing with racial issues yet to be made. He has produced a story, directed it with such sensitivity with an outstanding cast that it absolutely serves not only every ward the film industry can give but also the recognition of everyone working for equal rights.  The script is brilliant, rich in humor and pathos, and very, very intelligent.

The synopsis is too brief but offers the flavor of the film: BLACK OR WHITE is the story of a grandfather Elliot (Kevin Costner) who when his wife Carol (Jennifer Ehle) is killed in an automobile accident is suddenly left to care for his beloved granddaughter Eloise (Jillian Estell)  a child born to their daughter impregnated at age 17 by an African American junkie Reggie (Andr Holland): the daughter dies in childbirth and who died in childbirth. When her paternal grandmother Rowena (Octavia Spencer) seeks custody with the help of her brother Jeremiah (Anthony Mackie), the little girl is torn between two families who love her deeply. With the best intentions at heart, both families fight for what they feel is right and are soon forced to confront their true feelings about race, forgiveness, and understanding. Anchored by an all-star cast and based on real events, the movie is a look at two seemingly different worlds, in which nothing is as simple as black or white.

In addition to the brilliant cast listed above there are cameos by some rather extraordinary actors  Paula Newsome (a gifted and rising star who plays the judge), Mpho Koaho who plays Eloises tutor, and Joe Chrest  Elliots attorney partner and best friend.

The film belongs to Costner, Spencer and Estell  and it could not be in stronger hands. Highly Recommended. Grady Harp, November 15

Possible spoilers.  Rather than just make a movie about child custody issues the old fashion way, director and writer Mike Binder ("The Upside of Anger") tosses in generation gaps and race relations into the mix.

Kevin Costner stars as Elliot Anderson, a well to do attorney who has just lost his wife to an automobile accident as the movie opens.  The couple have raised 9 year old Eloise (Jillian Estell) since birth, complications of which killed their 17 year old daughter.  The girl's father, Reggie (Andre Holland), a black man who has been in trouble with the law, is a drug addict, has spent time in jail and has never shown any interest in his daughter.  Reggie's mother, Rowena Jeffers (Oscar winner, Octavia Spencer) now wants shared custody of her granddaughter.  Elliot balks, but also has no clear plan as to how he will continue to raise his granddaughter on his own.

Angry at the world and the cards he's been dealt, Elliot takes up drinking.  You just knew he had to have some vices, otherwise he was just too nice a guy.  The booze, the anger, his child care frustrations and the legal action taken by Rowena and her attorney brother, Jeremiah (Anthony Mackie) are becoming more difficult to face.  Where the film loses me is the fact that Rowena has to even go to court.  She is clearly a caring woman, living in central L. A. with a house full of shirt tail relatives.  And when Elliot visits, he seems to like everyone, and they him.  So what's the beef?  A little time with Grandma Rowena would seem to be an easy accommodation.

When Rowena brings Reggie back into the picture, Elliot balks and prepares for a fight.  He has clearly never gotten over the fact that a then 23 year old, Reggie impregnated his then 17 year old daughter and he was never aware of any of it.  Some of the best scenes are in the courtroom.  In a long scene, Jeremiah questions Elliot about his relationship with black people.  As we begin to squirm, he provides an answer that would seem to be honest from most people's perspective.

The movie is far from perfect.  For one thing it jumps uncomfortably back and forth between being a comedy and being a drama.  The scene where Elliot has to tell Eloise that her grandmother has been killed is just plain uncomfortable.  With custody at issue, couldn't Elliot curtail the drinking?  After all, he's not an alcoholic, he's just mad at the world.  Taken as a whole, there are some strong performances especially Costner and young Jillian.

The Blu ray disc comes with 1080p video resolution and a 2.40:1 aspect ratio.  The presentation is excellent and typical of the great video we see these days on modern films.  Strong color, terrific detail and deep black levels are evident and consistent throughout the film.  Some of the color tone and hues seem a little too Hollywood, eschewing reality but that would be a filmmaker's choice not a problematic transfer.  The audio is excellent as well with a fine DTS-HD Master Audio 5.1 track.  This is a film heavy on dialog and it is well presented, mostly centered and up front.  A few scenes like the pool party at Elliot's house provide some excellent surround opportunities.  Not much coming from the .1 as you might expect.  Subtitles are available in Spanish and English SDH.  Extras include a "making of" short, a trailer and a couple promos.  Recommended.

I really enjoyed this movie.

Young Eloise never knew her mother . She died the day Eloise was born. Her father is a drug addict, so her Caucasian grandparents raised her from the day their daughter died. Now her Caucasian grandmother is dead and that leaves her grandfather to raise her alone. He is loving and caring, but he is drinking too much. Her African American grandmother wants full custody of Eloise . Eloise's father shows up at the custody battle and a battle it becomes .

As you watch this movie you will ask yourself so many questions. Who has the right to raise Eloise? What needs to be done in the best interest of Eloise now and as she grows up? Can grandparents in two different environments work together to nurture and raise this beautiful child who loved them all?

There are misunderstandings, the lack of forgiveness and then forgiveness, feelings of hopelessness, anger, sorrow, there is redemption, and lots of love. You will see two different family groups who love Eloise. It is a complicated matter, but Eloise knows all along who she wants to live with.

The movie is based on real events. It is an emotional movie and issue, but I think you will come away with a feeling that these family members are going to do what is right for Eloise.

I am a huge Kevin Costner fan and the subject hit close to home with me. I have to say that I was not disappointed in this at all, and in some ways it was actually better than I was hoping it would be.
